events.target_title: MappingNotify event freezes drawing windows in Gnome for ~100ms

note.body:
I'm working off popos (or Pop! OS), and I've been plagued with the same issue, but this fix worked for me. For some reason the init commands have never worked on here (might be something I did), but you don't need the first one, and replacing "sudo init 5" with just a restart works just as well. 

Fantastic find Wigglyboy!

I made it simple like (in ipython3):
```
In [4]:  from gi.repository import GExiv2
/usr/bin/ipython3:1: PyGIWarning: GExiv2 was imported without specifying a version first. Use gi.require_version('GExiv2', '0.10') before import to ensure that the right version gets loaded.
  #! /bin/sh
In [6]: a = GExiv2.Metadata("15h58m30-NIKON_D7500.nef")

In [7]: a.get_comment() #tag missing

In [8]: a.set_comment("") #set empty value

In [9]: a.get_comment() #retrieve the next value 
Out[9]: 'lang="x-default" '
```

events.target_title: Update Gnome Shell extensions from the command line

note.body:
Couldn't `org.gnome.Shell.Extensions.CheckForUpdates` be used for this (defined [here](https://github.com/GNOME/gnome-shell/blame/ebf77748a8477eb712287273b4b92a8e9a189e22/data/dbus-interfaces/org.gnome.Shell.Extensions.xml#L214) and implemented [here](https://github.com/GNOME/gnome-shell/blame/ebf77748a8477eb712287273b4b92a8e9a189e22/js/ui/extensionDownloader.js#L154))?
```
dbus-send --session --print-reply --type=method_call --dest=org.gnome.Shell /org/gnome/Shell org.gnome.Shell.Extensions.CheckForUpdates
```
Unfortunately, this fails on my GNOME Shell 3.34.2 with the following error:
```
gnome-shell[4608]: JS ERROR: Exception in method call: CheckForUpdates: TypeError: Main.extensionManager.extensions is undefined
checkForUpdates/<@resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/extensionDownloader.js:157:9
checkForUpdates@resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/extensionDownloader.js:156:5
CheckForUpdates@resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/shellDBus.js:320:9
_handleMethodCall@resource:///org/gnome/gjs/modules/overrides/Gio.js:327:67
_wrapJSObject/<@resource:///org/gnome/gjs/modules/overrides/Gio.js:404:16
 ```
Currently, I'm using [this script](https://gist.github.com/N-Coder/9ec0eb11c2f14013c112e1468c708b30) (which is heavily inspired by the implementation of the "chrome-gnome-shell" daemon) to automatically click all the green update buttons and then disable unused extensions again. Of course, this probably needs a shell restart afterwards, but I usually don't want to quit all my applications (which seems to be a new thing under wayland) just for that.

events.target_title: gnome-session[823]: WARNING: Could not parse desktop file orca-autostart.desktop or it references a not found TryExec binary

note.body: Having spurious warnings in logs makes debugging other (real) issues more complicated.

events.target_title: Please watch the CanGraphical property on logind Seat objects before spawning a graphical login on a seat

note.body:
I've been hitting this bug for many months now on Arch Linux. Took me a while to get around to debugging this. Meanwhile many Arch Linux users are perpetrating [the work-around to bake KMS drivers into initramfs](https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Kernel_mode_setting#Early_KMS_start), but that's not a proper solution.

Logs: https://gist.github.com/intgr/a7eee474994e8a845405a7466ac2ebc2

Please fix, it's really disappointing to see design flaws that were known about 7 years ago bite users.

(Issue https://github.com/systemd/systemd/issues/10435 helped me in finding this)

events.target_title: Please watch the CanGraphical property on logind Seat objects before spawning a graphical login on a seat

note.body:
Thanks @mraudsepp, that's very helpful and solves my issue.

I created an Arch Linux bug report to integrate this patch: https://bugs.archlinux.org/task/64985

note.body: Hi. Thank you for the reply. I am not using brew but macports. I have never tested that before. It came up from an issue that I have with[TexText under Inkscape](https://github.com/textext/textext/issues/150). I tried it as well using Python 3.7 (and using the port py37-gobject3) and in that case after executing `from gi.repository import Gtk` I don't get the prompt back (seems to get stuck).

'glib/4430778@@glib-2.0@sha/guuid.c.o' 'glib/4430778@@glib-2.0@sha/gvariant.c.o' 'glib/4430778@@glib-2.0@sha/gvariant-core.c.o' 'glib/4430778@@glib-2.0@sha/gvariant-parser.c.o' 'glib/4430778@@glib-2.0@sha/gvariant-serialiser.c.o' 'glib/4430778@@glib-2.0@sha/gvarianttypeinfo.c.o' 'glib/4430778@@glib-2.0@sha/gvarianttype.c.o' 'glib/4430778@@glib-2.0@sha/gversion.c.o' 'glib/4430778@@glib-2.0@sha/gwakeup.c.o' 'glib/4430778@@glib-2.0@sha/gprintf.c.o' 'glib/4430778@@glib-2.0@sha/glib-unix.c.o' 'glib/4430778@@glib-2.0@sha/gspawn.c.o' 'glib/4430778@@glib-2.0@sha/giounix.c.o' 'glib/4430778@@glib-2.0@sha/gthread-posix.c.o' 'glib/libcharset/6e4c96c@@charset@sta/localcharset.c.o' -I/usr/include -I/usr/pkg/include -I/usr/pkg/include/python3.8 -L/usr/lib -L/usr/pkg/lib -Wl,--as-needed -Wl,--no-undefined -shared -fPIC -Wl,--start-group -Wl,-soname,libglib-2.0.so.0 -O2 -Wl,-R/usr/lib -Wl,-R/usr/pkg/lib -Wl,-z,nodelete -Wl,-Bsymbolic-functions -Wl,-R/usr/pkg/lib /usr/pkg/lib/libpcre.so -pthread -lintl -Wl,--end-group
```
/usr/bin/ld: error: undefined symbol: environ
>>> referenced by genviron.c
>>>               glib/4430778@@glib-2.0@sha/genviron.c.o:(g_listenv)

/usr/bin/ld: error: undefined symbol: environ
>>> referenced by genviron.c
>>>               glib/4430778@@glib-2.0@sha/genviron.c.o:(g_listenv)

/usr/bin/ld: error: undefined symbol: environ
>>> referenced by genviron.c
>>>               glib/4430778@@glib-2.0@sha/genviron.c.o:(g_get_environ)

/usr/bin/ld: error: undefined symbol: environ
>>> referenced by gspawn.c
>>>               glib/4430778@@glib-2.0@sha/gspawn.c.o:(fork_exec_with_fds)
clang: error: linker command failed with exit code 1 (use -v to see invocation)
ninja: build stopped: subcommand failed.
*** Error code 1

Stop.
bmake[1]: stopped in /usr/pkgsrc/devel/glib2
*** Error code 1

Stop.
```
Actually, like said by @lantw, the problems with environ are known on FreeBSD: [devel/glib20: ld-elf.so.1: /usr/local/lib/libglib-2.0.so.0: Undefined symbol "environ" (WITH_LLD_IS_LD)](https://bugs.freebsd.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=220103)
I tested to add extern char **environ but it does not seem to be sufficient to solve the problem.
I initially passed -Db_lundef=false to meson but own suggest to me to make environ a "weak" symbol.

events.target_title: Fix build error with FreeBSD
Fix build error with FreeBSD

note.body:
Maybe because I use the pkgsrc framework to build glib and you don't.

Maybe it works with /usr/bin/ld.bfd but I think it is easier for us to have a small patch for this package than hack it to use a different linker.

Maybe this bug is an artifact and you can safely ignore my merge request.

events.target_title: Fix build error with FreeBSD

note.body:
>  FreeBSD CI machine uses `-Db_lundef=false`.

Could it be added to the meson configuration file please?

events.target_title: Build failure in DAAP plugin due to deprecated G_CONST_RETURN usage in libdmapsharing library
Build failure in DAAP plugin due to deprecated G_CONST_RETURN usage in libdmapsharing library

note.body: Hi .. the actual error message is a const error, which is in the bug description. Should this be included in the subject ?

events.target_title: Build failure in DAAP plugin due to deprecated G_CONST_RETURN usage in libdmapsharing library

note.body:
The issue is due to recent glib versions ( glib 2.62 in Ubuntu 19.10 ) which have made G_CONST_RETURN a deprecated warning. With -Werror the compilation fails. Later versions of glib have a better warning message than just a "error: const" message. 

The deprecation issue is fixed in libdmapsharing recently.

https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libdmapsharing/commit/3d79874066e1a1c1bba646135cf5fc5811b0eb55

A new release need to be pushed to fix the compiler error / warning.

events.target_title: Glib Installation Error:-  meson.build:1919:2: ERROR: Dependency "mount" not found, tried pkgconfig and cmake
Incorrect Histogram Arithmetic Mean Values

note.body:
How many people are aware of equation **mean_absolute = mean \ (2^bitsPerChannel - 1)**?

Why not provide two fields for the mean values of histograms, and let users decide which units they want to use?

E.g.:
One field for standard RGB units [0 to 255].
One field for RGB units stated as [0 to 1.0].

Here is an example: http://colorizer.org

Thank you for your consideration,

Daniel Guibord

events.target_title: Saving to PDF changes text's font and size

note.body:
I have an xcf file which I've been working on for a few years using older versions of GIMP. I opened it in version 2.10.14 today and tried making a few changes, but there are a lot of problems that I'm noticing, perhaps related to this.

1) The font sizes within the file seems to be corrupted somehow. That is, a text block which was 90 px in the past, when being clicked on, is shown as 21 px. The preview is still at 90 px. But the moment I click the dragbars to resize the text layer, it immediately shrinks to 21px and then I have to change the fonts manually again.

2) When exporting to PNG, everything is fine.

3) When exporting to PDF, these problems are happening

    * The font sizes are all small.
    * Hidden layers are not omitted.


I'm attaching the latest xcf file and the old and new pdf outputs.

(Unfortunately I don't have the backup of the old xcf file)

note.body:
Open file-png.exe and if it says "The code execution cannot proceed because **libgimpui-2.O-O.dll** was not found."
It's a typo because they should be **zeroes** not **Os**. How could someone fail at programming something simple? To avoid typing in **Os** instead of **zeroes**, use the keypad! **It's on the right side of the keyboard!** But, nope! That someone was lazy! There needs to be a keyboard that has the **zero** key **to the left** of the **one** key instead of **to the right** of the **nine** key. It needs to be intented.

events.target_title: About screen Close button does not work
Tiff files generated by GIMP cannot be deleted or used by other programs.

note.body: I had the same issue with files generated with GIMP. As often is the case, this is a Windows problem, in this case it is Windows Explorer. All you have to do is to terminate Windows Explorer (simply stop the "Windows Explorer" task in the Task Manager after opening Task Manager with Ctrl/Alt/Del). Before doing this, you need to start another application where you can access all files in the folder tree of your drive. I used 7-Zip, but I guess other archive programs such as Winrar etc. will also work. If Explorer doesn´t run in parallel, all files can be deleted. At least it worked for me!

events.target_title: Tiff files generated by GIMP cannot be deleted or used by other programs.

note.body: It is not sufficient to simply close Explorer because it is running in the background. You have to terminate the process. Once you do, the Windows Task bar will vanish, so all programs for further use have to be opened before terminating Explorer.

events.target_title: Tiff files generated by GIMP cannot be deleted or used by other programs.

note.body: Then use Strg Alt Del to log out. After the new login, the task bar will reappear.

events.target_title: opensuse Tumbleweed Express install doesn't work

note.body:
Here is what SUSE said:
https://bugzilla.opensuse.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1160025
Ancor Gonzalez Sosa 2020-01-17 07:48:41 UTC

As I understand this, the Gnome Boxes included in Ubuntu ships an incorrect AutoYaST profile which contains a wrong language code and that does not fit the image it uses (the image provides several images but the profile doesn't specify which one to install).

So this is a bug in Gnome Boxes or in Ubuntu. I don't see anything to be fixed in the openSUSE or AutoYaST side. AutoYaST is correctly reporting the two errors in the profile.

events.target_title: GIMP 2.10.14 crashes

note.body:
I'm having the exact same problem.  Fresh install of Windows 10 Pro version 1909 installed Dec 24, 2019 OS Build 1836.418 on a HP Z800 12 core Zeon CPU 2.8 ghz with 32 GB ram.  Installed RawTherapee, it works. Installed Photomatix 5, it works.  Tried PaintXP, doesn't work at all, gives a long cryptic error message.  

Intalled GIMP 2.10.14, nothing.  Changed compatibility to Win 7, Win XP, Win 8, Win 95, nothing.  In the compatibility troubleshooter, there is a 'test compatibility' button.  When you click it, GIMP shows up in the task manager list for a second or two, but nothing happens.  If you click it repeatedly, several instances of GIMP will show up in the list, and each disappears in order in the same pattern as you clicked the button about a second or so later.  Complete mystery, No ideas.  Uninstalled and reinstalled, as admin, etc.  Nothing.  

Uninstalled, downloaded GIMP 2.8.22 and installed.  Seems to work.  But Windows 10 does not seem to like GIMP 2.10.  Anybody have any ideas? Thanks

events.target_title: document gnomerc on help.gnome.org
document gnomerc on help.gnome.org

note.body:
Hi Andre,

Thank you for taking interest in .gnomerc.

> Where exactly to find a file called .gnomerc on a system?

It lives in $HOME, when it is present.

> Why do you think it is a "critical file"?

The name itself implies the importance of the file, I think.  For bash,
what file is more important than .bashrc?  Lynx, screen, bochs, and xfig
all have their equivalent RC files ($HOME/.lynxrc etc.).

It is critical for the same reason as .bashrc is critical: it allows me to
configure the shell from a script, obviating a lot of manual puttering
about I would have to otherwise do on each login.

> Which exact GNOME version is this about?

I am running GNOME 3.30.2.

- James P.

events.target_title: document gnomerc on help.gnome.org

note.body:
> GNOME by default uses dconf/gsettings for its settings these days.

I believe many aspects of GNOME are still controlled by environment
variables.  For example, in the discussion around a gnome-terminal bug, we
have

: Please double check you don't have G_MESSAGES_DEBUG=... environment
variable set anywhere
(https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-terminal/issues/42)

Setting environment variables like that is perhaps one use for .gnomerc.

The critical application for me, which I use daily, is suggested in my bug
report: at session open time I have to open a terminal window (preferably
gnome-terminal, but xterm if I must) which runs a shell script
interactively and which leaves me finally with an open, useful terminal
running the Unix CLI shell.

I definately do accomplish this today in GNOME 3.30.2 (on Debian 10) using
.gnomerc, so I think your search perhaps fell short.  The code may be in X
or Wayland, but it is difficult to understand why it is named .gnomerc if
this is the case.

My (quite functional) .gnomerc looks like this (some of it, the rest is
unimportant)

: ~$ ls -ld .gnomerc

: -rw-r--r-- 1 powellj powellj 840 oct.  31 15:28 .gnomerc

: ~$ head .gnomerc

: #!/bin/bash

: export TEXINPUTS=$TEXINPUTS:/usr/share/texmf/tex/bbdb:.

: # gtk-redshift -l 45.52307:-122.681296 &

: # tracker-control -k

: # sleep is necessary before starting artbox cos the db is saved on a
thumb
: # drive which will only eventually automount after the xsession is
started.
: # sleep 5

: # xeyes &

: # sleep 5

: # xmessage "insert meow please"

: ~$


This excerpt indicates some of the utility of .gnomerc.  Before GNOME Shell
added 'Night Mode' there was gtk-redshift, which I have been using for
years to the same effect.  How am I supposed to accomplish workarounds to
GNOME Shell limitations without .gnomerc?

So, again I would definately like to see this function documented, and to
be pointed to that documentation.

Thanks for taking the time to look at this.  I won't argue it's beyond
beginner material.  In my opinion it belongs at help.gnome.org but as I
said there's no place to report a bug for that site that I can locate today.

I am also curious if you might suggest some other, more GNOME-like way of
accomplishing my goal of configuring my GNOME Shell environment (invoking
the full power of linux and not just some GNOME dconf settings)
automatically at login, and launching interactive shell scripts at login
automatically?

yours truly,
  James P.

events.target_title: document gnomerc on help.gnome.org

note.body:
These are the details of gnomerc on Debian 10.  Short story: it's part of
the gnome-session package, and cleanly invoked during init.

Details: several mentions of the file in the system (grep results follow):


/etc/X11/Xsession.d/55gnome-session_gnomerc:# If we are running the GNOME
session, source ~/.gnomerc
/etc/X11/Xsession.d/55gnome-session_gnomerc:    GNOMERC=$HOME/.gnomerc
/usr/share/doc/gnome-session/README.Debian:.gnomerc file the following:
/var/lib/dpkg/info/gnome-session-common.list:/etc/X11/Xsession.d/55gnome-session_gnomerc
/var/backups/dpkg.status.0: /etc/X11/Xsession.d/55gnome-session_gnomerc
0d6fbd1c962e79b114c8e9278c820232

More details: the dpkg.status.0 file lists gnomerc in gnome-session:

: Status: install ok installed

: Priority: optional

: Section: gnome

: Installed-Size: 1208

: Maintainer: Debian GNOME Maintainers
<pkg-gnome-maintainers@lists.alioth.debi$
: Architecture: all

: Source: gnome-session

: Version: 3.30.1-2

: Breaks: evince (<< 3.30)

: Conffiles:

:  /etc/X11/Xsession.d/55gnome-session_gnomerc
0d6fbd1c962e79b114c8e9278c820232
: Description: GNOME Session Manager - common files

:  The GNOME Session Manager is in charge of starting the core components

:  of the GNOME desktop, and applications that should be launched at

:  login time. It also features a way to save and restore currently

:  running applications.

:  .

:  This package contains the translations, data files and startup scripts

:  which are common to the GNOME and GNOME fallback sessions.


There's no indication of it being Debian-only...?

Many thanks.

- JP

events.target_title: document gnomerc on help.gnome.org

note.body:
I can also do my own homework with respect to "I am also curious if you
might suggest some other, more GNOME-like way of accomplishing my goal".  I
have already noticed this text from README.Debian:

: Applications at startup

: -----------------------

:

: Upon startup, gnome-session starts the following applications:

:  - Saved session: if you have saved a session, it is located in

:    ~/.config/gnome-session/saved-session/. You can enable automatic

:    session saving or manually save it in the "Startup Applications"

:    configuration applet.

:  - Autostart applications: applications shipping a .desktop file in

:    /usr/share/gnome/autostart or /etc/xdg/autostart. This includes the

:    keyring manager, the settings daemon, nautilus and the power

:    manager. They can be selectively disabled in the configuration

:    applet.

:  - Required components: they are listed in the

:    /usr/share/gnome-session/sessions/*.desktop file corresponding to the

:    current session (gnome or gnome-fallback).


So please don't bother about that, I can follow up on this.

- JP

Thanks Michael. I do use Mac OS X and have recently upgraded to Catalina,
also, this is happening with Gimp 2.10.14.  While I cannot save images
processed with Gimp to Desktop, so far I can save them to a file in iCloud.
When I first processed an image after just downloading Gimp 2.10.14, I was
asked for permission for Gimp to view my desktop.  This seemed fishy to me,
so I declined.  Then the trouble began.

I made a mistake in my last message.  I don't 'save as' the gimp-processed
image to iCloud.  I save it to harddrive>users> house icon with my name.
Then I can move it to the desktop.
I hope this helps others. (This is with a macbook pro with Catalina
(10.15.2) and Gimp 2.10.14)

note.body:
sorry, it seems that the problem comes from Wayland and the selection of the clipboard which is different from that of Xorg.

I guess the problem is self.clipboard.wait_is_uris_available().

It works normally under Xorg and Wayland if I don't look for uris in the clipboard ...

Is there another way to display the item in the menu only if the clipboard contains uris ?

Too bad because everything works perfectly under Xorg with this method ...

events.target_title: What is gdm's default on-screen keyboard?
What is gdm's default on-screen keyboard?

note.body:
Hi @aklapper and thanks for the reply.
I indeed wondered about the version difference, but note that 3.26 is the latest version I could find in https://help.gnome.org/admin/gdm/.

caribou isn't installed in my system.

Searching more within the repo, I can find:

```console
$ grep -R keyboard data/*
data/dconf/defaults/locks/00-upstream-settings-locks:/org/gnome/desktop/a11y/keyboard/enable
```

I'll assume that you're just delegating the responsibility to launch the keyboard to gnome, and it's up to him to decide which software to use.
I suppose that's where a desktop manager comes in handy, while I need to set manual rules for everything when using just a window manager.

Gnome doesn't say much in its documentation:
https://help.gnome.org/users/gnome-help/stable/keyboard-osk.html.en

Wondering why this is so well hidden.
